    • milestoneF

      public void milestoneF() throws java.lang.Exception
      A single text file containing all the correct INSERT..INTO statements for data which involves two entities. DATA FILE HERO.CSV:\\ p,l,k,h,f\\ 101,'Eric Noel','2001-12-25','Eric Noel', 'Santa Clause' SQL PRAGMA foreign_keys=ON; BEGIN TRANSACTION; -- NB might already exist -- INSERT OR IGNORE INTO R(p,l,k) VALUES( 101, 'Eric Noel', '2001-012-25' ); -- assuming this does not exist INSERT INTO G(p,h,f) VALUES (101,'Eric Noel','Santa Clause'); COMMIT;
      Throws:
      java.sql.SQLException
      java.lang.Exception

    • milestoneG

      public void milestoneG() throws java.sql.SQLException
      The database also needs indexes in the database to speed up possible queries involving the combination of entities and attribute constraints. Add code to establish what indexes are present and include CREATE INDEX statements in your DDL to create these. You should have a set of statements of the form (what follows is just an example): CREATE INDEX planets_id ON F (a);
      Throws:
      java.sql.SQLException

    • milestoneH

      public void milestoneH()
      If the database structure is modified after creation it is possible for tables to be returned in an order that would break key constraints â€“ i.e. a table depends on a yet to be created table. CREATE statements need sorting based on foreign keys. As with (g) but ensure the CREATE TABLE statements are in the â€˜correctâ€™ order.
